head.title: Rising Gas Prices: Look in the Mirror

hedline.hl1: Rising Gas Prices: Look in the Mirror

abstract.p: Grace A Duren letter on June 22 article urges Americans to conserve gasoline instead of turning rising prices into presidential election issues

block.p: Re ''Price of Gasoline Emerges as Issue in Bush-Gore Race'' (front page, June 22):
Why do we Americans feel that we have a right to unlimited and cheap gasoline?
Re ''Price of Gasoline Emerges as Issue in Bush-Gore Race'' (front page, June 22):
Why do we Americans feel that we have a right to unlimited and cheap gasoline?

Our reaction to the high price of gasoline seems to be to make it a political issue by seeking someone to blame. Or we look for short-term ''solutions'' like putting pressure on OPEC or relaxing Environmental Protection Agency standards.

Instead, we might try using less gasoline, by driving less and instead, car-pooling, walking, biking or using public transportation when possible. When we do drive, we could save greatly on gasoline by using smaller, energy-efficient cars rather than gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles and other large cars.
Despite polling of voter sentiment cited by Democratic officials in your article, I am one voter who does not believe that the price of gasoline is ''the No. 1 problem in the country.''
GRACE A. DUREN Ann Arbor, Mich., June 22, 2000
